facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 32 of 1956 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 32 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 7 and 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 817 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 7 and 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 817 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 7 and 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 817 of 1955. Porus A. Mehta, R. Ganapathy Iyer and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave by Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala against the order of the High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special Rag leave by Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing an appeal by the State against the acquittal of the appellant of an offence under s. 92 of the Factories Act, 1948  Act LXIII of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, for his working the Wadia Mahal Salt Works situate at Wadala, Bombay, without obtaining a licence under s. 6 of the said Act read with r. 4 of the rules framed under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant acquitted by trial court of offence under s.92 of Factories Act, 1948 for working Wadia Mahal Salt Works without licence under s.6 read with r.4.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special Rag leave by Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing an appeal by the State against the acquittal of the appellant of an offence under s. 92 of the Factories Act, 1948  Act LXIII of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, for his working the Wadia Mahal Salt Works situate at Wadala, Bombay, without obtaining a licence under s. 6 of the said Act read with r. 4 of the rules framed under the Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed appeal by the State against acquittal and convicted appellant.

anchor.surface_text: against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing an appeal by the State against the acquittal of the appellant of an offence under s. 92 of the Factories Act, 1948  Act LXIII of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, for his working the Wadia Mahal Salt Works situate at Wadala, Bombay, without obtaining a licence under s. 6 of the said Act read with r. 4 of the rules framed under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant worked the Wadia Mahal Salt Works situate at Wadala, Bombay, without obtaining a licence.

anchor.surface_text: for his working the Wadia Mahal Salt Works situate at Wadala, Bombay, without obtaining a licence under s. 6 of the said Act read with r. 4 of the rules framed under the Act. The main question for determination in this appeal is whether these Salt Works companye within the definition of the word factory under cl.  m  of s. 2 of the Act.

facts.text: The Salt Works extend over an area of about two hundred and fifty acres.

anchor.surface_text: The Salt Works extend over an area of about two hundred and fifty acres. Some of the other salt works, however, have even larger areas. The only buildings on this land companysist of temporary shelters companystructed for the resident labour and for an office.

facts.text: Only buildings on the land consist of temporary shelters for resident labour and office.

anchor.surface_text: The only buildings on this land companysist of temporary shelters companystructed for the resident labour and for an office. At a few places, pucca platforms exist for fixing the water pump when required to pump water from the sea.

facts.text: Pucca platforms exist for fixing water pump to pump water from the sea.

anchor.surface_text: At a few places, pucca platforms exist for fixing the water pump when required to pump water from the sea. When number required, this pump is kept in the office.

facts.text: Entire area of Salt Works is open except mentioned constructions; has bunds on sea side to prevent flooding.

anchor.surface_text: With the exception of the companystructions already mentioned, the entire area of the Salt Works is open. On the sea side, it has bunds in order to prevent sea water flooding the salt pans.

facts.text: Ten or more workers working or were working on any day of preceding twelve months in premises where manufacturing process carried on.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  m  of s. 2 of the Act reads factory means any premises including the precincts thereof- whereon ten or more workers are working, or were working on any day of the preceding twelve months, and in any part of which a manufacturing process is being carried on with the aid of power, or is ordinarily so carried on,

facts.text: Workers have at times to work at night; some women workers employed; workers need rest, food at mid-day, drinking water, first-aid.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the workers have at times to work at night that some women workers are employed that workers have to take rest that they have to take food at about mid-day that they do require drinking water and that first-aid things are kept in the office room.

facts.text: Process at Salt Works: conversion of sea water into crystals of salt.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to this question depends on the meaning of the word premises in the definition of the word factory and on the determination whether what is done at this Salt Works in companynection with the companyversion of sea water into crystals of salt companyes within the definition of the expression manufacturing process in cl.  k  of s. 2 of the Act.

facts.text: Sea water taken into reservoirs at high tide twice a month; labourers work sluice gates or pump, sometimes at night.

anchor.surface_text: For said production the sea water is taken into the Reservoirs at high water tide twice during a month. The high tides take place on about nine or ten days in a month, five days during day time and four times at night. Some of the labourers are detained for this work but they are also number required to be present the whole time, when the evaporation is going on.

facts.text: Labourers fill crystallizing beds, watch density of brine, ensure no excess density or contamination, scrape and collect salt crystals, grade by sieving, bag salt.

anchor.surface_text: Once the brine is let into the crystallising beds, its surface is number to be disturbed for four or five days. After this, the labourer has to be careful to see that the density does number exceed a certain limit and that the other kinds of salt companytained in the brine are number deposited, thus companytaminating the sodium chloride  companymon salt  already formed. This they learn by experience. Sifting and storing then begins. The labourer has also to refill the crystallizing beds with fresh, brine.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 27, 1961 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta, R. Ganapathy Iyer and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant. S. Bindra, R. H. Dhebar and T. M. Sen, for the respondent. 1961. January 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

facts.text: Salt Works has open marshy area surrounded by mud embankment above highest tide mark; sluice gates for sea water intake and discharge.

anchor.surface_text: A salt work mainly companysists of an open marshy area, surrounded by mud embankment, the height of which is above the highest tide water mark in that locality to prevent inundation. In this embankment, sluice gates are provided with suitable places to take in and discharge the sea water and the waste water respectively.

facts.text: Inner area divided into compartments for storage of sea brine of different densities; salt stored on platform, weighed, bagged, carried to railway or port.

anchor.surface_text: The inner enclosed area is divided into companypartments for the storage of sea brine of different densities. When the salt is formed, it is stored on the platform by the laborers engaged in the manufacture. It is then weighed, bagged and carried to Railway Station or to a port of shipment

facts.text: Appellant contended that premises means buildings and open land not covered.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended for the appellant that the expres. sion premises in the definition of the word factory means buildings and that mere open land is number companyered by the word premises and as there are numberbuildings except temporary sheds on the Salt Works, the Salt Works cannot be said to be a factory .

facts.text: Court held Salt Works come within definition of factory as premises where manufacturing process carried on.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Salt Works would companye within the meaning of the expression premises in the definition of the word factory and would be a factory if the work carried on there companyes within the definition of manufacturing process .

facts.text: Process of converting sea water into salt is a manufacturing process involving treatment and adaptation of sea water.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the process of companyverting sea water into salt carried on on the appellants Salt Works companyes within the definition of manufacturing process in el.  k  of s. 2 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant convicted of working factory without licence.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above,, we are of opinion that the appellants Salt Works do companye within the definition of the word ,factory and that the appellant has been rightly companyvicted of the offence of working the factory without obtaining a licence.

issues.text: The main question for determination in this appeal is whether these Salt Works companye within the definition of the word factory under cl. m of s. 2 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The main question for determination in this appeal is whether these Salt Works companye within the definition of the word factory under cl. m  of s. 2 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the expression premises in the definition of the word factory means buildings and that mere open land is number companyered by the word premises

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the appellant that the expression premises in the definition of the word factory means buildings and that mere open land is number companyered by the word premises and as there are numberbuildings except temporary sheds on the Salt Works,

anchor.surface_text: The second contention for the appellant is that the process of companyverting sea water into salt does number amount to manufacturing process as numberprocess for i  making, altering, repairing, ornamenting, finishing, packing, oiling, washing, cleaning, breaking up, demolishing, or otherwise treating or adapting, any article or substance with a view to its use, sale,

arguments.claim: The expression 'premises' in the definition of factory means buildings only and mere open land is not covered by the word premises

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the appellant that the expression premises in the definition of the word factory means buildings and that mere open land is not covered by the word premises and as there are nobuildings except temporary sheds on the Salt Works, the Salt Works cannot be said to be a factory .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er frequently found in instruments and in Acts of Parliament as meaning land or houses, e.g., the Public Health Act, 1875, s. 4, where premises includ

arguments.court_reasoning: Premises is generic term including land or buildings; dictionary meanings; 'including precincts' enlarges scope; internal evidence from ss.7,85,93; purposive interpretation for worker welfare

arguments.claim: Expression 'premises including precincts' indicates premises meant only buildings as buildings alone can have precincts and open land cannot

anchor.surface_text: The expression premises including precincts it has been urged, clearly indicates that in the context of the definition of the word factory , premises meant only buildings as buildings alone can have precincts and there can be no precincts of any open land.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: re that all or any of the provisions of the Act shall apply to any place wherein a manufacturing process is carried on with or without the aid of powe

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Including' enlarges scope of premises, not restricts; buildings need not have precincts

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished due to historical Factory Acts context limited to mills with power; later Acts evolved

arguments.claim: Salt pans not factories except where equipped with building used in manufacture (Chief Inspector opinion)

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to the expression of opinion by the Chief Inspector of Factories in his letter to the Deputy Salt Commissioner, Bombay, in support of the appellants contention that salt works as such do not come within the definition of the word factory

court_response_anchor.surface_text: have made reference to it only in view of the reference made by the appellants to an opinion expressed by the Chief Inspector of Factories in his let

arguments.court_reasoning: Opinion of authority not binding; no final view known; parties did not earlier contend

arguments.claim: Word 'premises' has come to refer to land or buildings or both depending on context; generic term

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with this contention. The word premises has not come to refer to either land or buildings or to both, depending on the context. The meanings of the word premises in various lexicons and dictionaries are given below

arguments.claim: 'Including precincts' enlarges scope of premises, does not restrict to buildings

anchor.surface_text: This expression premises including precincts does not necessarily mean that the premises must always have precincts. Even buildings need not have any precincts. The word including is not a term restricting the meaning of the word premises but is a term which enlarges the scope

arguments.claim: Internal evidence: s.7(1)(bb) requires notice mentioning owner of premises or building

anchor.surface_text: Sub-cl.  bb  of cl.  1  of s. 7 of the Act requires the occupier of a factory to mention in the written notice to be sent to the Chief Inspector before his occupying or using any premises as a factory, the name and address of the owner of the premises or building

arguments.claim: s.93: premises can have separate buildings leased to different occupiers

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s.  1  of s. 93 reads Where in any premises separate buildings are leased to different occupiers, for use as separate factories, the owner of the premises shall be responsible for the provision and maintenance of common facilities

arguments.claim: s.85: 'place' includes open land; Act applicable to manufacturing on open land

anchor.surface_text: Further, s. 85 empowers the State Government to declare that all or any of the provisions of the Act shall apply to any place wherein a manufacturing process is carried on with or without the aid of power

arguments.claim: Act is welfare legislation; cannot intend discrimination between workers in buildings vs open land

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rightly pointed out that the Act is for the welfare of the workers and deals with matters connected with the health, safety, welfare, working hours of the workers, employment of young persons and leave

arguments.claim: s.6 requires permission for site, not necessarily building

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act empowers the State Government to make rules requiring the previous permission in writing of the State Government or the Chief Inspector to be obtained for the site on which the factory is to be situated

arguments.claim: Kent v Astley distinguished: earlier Acts limited to powered mills; slate quarry not expressly included

anchor.surface_text: It is not clear from these observations alone why the slate quarries where work was carried on in the open air and not in building, was not held to be a factory on that account. This is, however, apparent when one considers

arguments.claim: 1937 Factories Act explicitly includes open air premises

anchor.surface_text: It may not be mentioned that the Factories Act, 1937 specifically provides in sub-s.  7  of s. 151 that premises shall not be excluded from the definition of a factory by reason only that they are open air premises

arguments.claim: Salt making involves human agency: sluice gates, filling beds, monitoring density, scraping, sieving, bagging

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is a travesty of language to say that although 47 workmen are working on these works, salt is made without the assistance of human agency Now, in this case there is nodoubt that the workmen employed

arguments.claim: Conversion of sea water to salt is treating/adapting substance with view to sale

anchor.surface_text: The processes carried out in the Salt Works and described above, come within the definition of manufacturing process inasmuch as salt can be said to have been manufactured from sea water by the process of treatment and adaptation

arguments.claim: Analogous to beer treatment in Sedgwick: changes unmarketable to marketable

anchor.surface_text: The observations in Sedgwick v. Watney Combe, Reid Company, Limited at page 463, support the view that the process undergone at the Salt Works is the process of treatment of sea water for the purpose of converting it into salt

arguments.claim: Analogous to Grove, Kaye: adapting for sale where finished article different

anchor.surface_text: The observations in Grove v. Lloyds British Testing Co. Ltd. at page 467 support the view that the conversion of sea water into salt amounts to adapting it for sale.

arguments.claim: Salt Works come within definition of factory; appellant rightly convicted

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above,, we are of opinion that the appellants Salt Works do come within the definition of the word ,factory and that the appellant has been rightly convicted of the offence of working the factory without obtaining a licence.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that the Salt Works would come within the meaning of the expression premises in the definition of the word factory and would be a factory if the work carried on there comes within the definition of manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Salt Works would come within the meaning of the expression premises in the definition of the word factory and would be a factory if the work carried on there comes within the definition

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meanings establish 'premises' as generic term for land, buildings or both; 'including precincts' enlarges scope; harmonious construction of ss.7(1)(bb), 85, 93 shows not limited to buildings; welfare purpose precludes discrimination.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the process of converting sea water into salt carried on on the appellants Salt Works comes within the definition of manufacturing process in cl. k of s. 2 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the process of converting sea water into salt carried on on the appellants Salt Works comes within the definition of manufacturing process in cl. k of s. 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Human agency in sluice operation, brine monitoring, scraping, sieving, bagging constitutes treating/adapting sea water (non-commercial) to salt (commercial) for sale; aided by natural forces; analogies to beer carbonation, pepper cleaning precedents.

holdings.text: In view of the above, we are of opinion that the appellants Salt Works do come within the definition of the word factory and that the appellant has been rightly convicted of the offence of working the factory without obtaining a licence.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above,, we are of opinion that the appellants Salt Works do come within the definition of the word ,factory and that the appellant has been rightly convicted of the offence of working the factory without obtaining a licence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines premises (open land qualifies), manufacturing process (sea water to salt), 10+ workers without power; applies s.2(m) definition; upholds s.92 conviction for no s.6 licence.
